am.pdf pdf false 1769557 AAM-PDF MCAT 111733 111733 S2468-8231(21)00350-3 10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111733 Scheme 1 A series of M-salen complexes considered in the present paper. M = AlIII, CrIII, MnIII, CoIII and ZnII. For Al and Co, the complexes of the salen ligand substituted with all the ionic liquids were studied. For Cr, Mn and Zn salen complexes, only the complexes of salen-Py ligand were calculated. The axial anion (counterion) for the complexes of the trivalent metals Al, Cr, Mn and Co is Cl-, and the Zn-salen complex has no axial anion. China Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry Key Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry of MOE School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing 210023 PR China Institute of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry of MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of bifunctional metal-salen complexes bearing ionic liquid substituents were investigated as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide (CO2) and epoxides using density functional theory (DFT) and energy span model. Detailed studies reveal that the three-step mechanism involving the ring-opening of propylene oxide (PO), CO2 insertion, and ring-closure to the cyclic carbonate is kinetically more favorable than the two-step mechanism. The effect of ionic liquids, epoxide substituents and metal center of the metal-salen complexes were explored. Amino functionalized ionic liquids substituents tethered to the salen ligand of the metal-salen complexes performed well. Epoxide substituents affect the cycloaddition mainly through the electronic effect and the substituent that lowers the negative charges of the ring carbon atom to be attacked favors the cycloaddition. When the salen ligand is fixed, the catalytic activity metal-salen complexes can be measured by the interaction between the oxygen atom (O) of epoxides and the central metal (M) and there is a linear relationship between the energy span and the M-O bond length, which can be used as a descriptor to screen CO2 conversion catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal salen Ionic liquid Cycloaddition DFT Energy span model 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is considered to be largely responsible for increasingly severe global warming, but it is also a highly desirable C1 feedstock as it is abundant, inexpensive and nontoxic [1,2]. The fixation of CO2 to valuable chemicals has been received considerable attention [3–7]. The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO) into propylene carbonate (PC) has been one of the most concerned reactions as it is an atom-economic and environment-benign process [8–10], because PC is often used as raw material for synthesis of polycarbonates and polymers, aprotic polar solvents and electrolytes in lithium batteries, as well as intermediate for pharmaceuticals [11–13]. However, it is still challenging to achieve highly efficient conversion of CO2 to PC, especially in the mild reaction conditions, because the energy barrier for the uncatalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with PO is about 200 kJ/mol. To promote the conversion, efforts have been made to develop homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems, such as metal-salen complexes [14–20], ionic liquids (ILs) [8,21–24], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [25,26], and etc. It is known that cooperative effects can significantly promote catalytic performance by synergistic activation through two or more active centers. Cooperativity can be realized by combination of multiple individual catalysts. On the one hand, metal-salen complexes, whose properties are easy to be modified by varying the steric and electronic properties about the metal centers that play the role of Lewis acid, have exhibited high activities and enantioselectivities. On the other hand, ionic liquids are eco-friendly and solvent-free and the anions are usually utilized as efficient nucleophiles. Combination of ionic liquids which provide nucleophiles with metal-salen complexes acting as Lewis acid centers can form unary bifunctional catalysts. Will such bifunctional catalysts acting as both Lewis acid and nucleophile enhance catalytic performance for CO2 conversion to propylene carbonate? In other words, can the two active centers work cooperatively for the CO2 cycloaddition? The answer is positive: the bifunctional catalysts having two active centers do exhibit high catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction [15]. In fact, several bifunctional catalytic systems including two or more active sites have been developed for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction [27–38]. For example, Al-salen (salen = N,N′-bis-(salicylidene)-cyclohexenediaminato) complexes which contain ionic liquid tethered to the salen ligand, Al-salen-Py and Al-salen-Im, were investigated for the conversion [15]. By Al-salen-Py and Al-salen-Im, we mean the Al-salen complexes with the salen ligand substituted by Py and Im ILs respectively (Scheme 1 ). Here, Py or Im denotes pyridinium or imidazolium IL. The experimental results demonstrate that although the cycloaddition reaction can be catalyzed alone either by an ionic liquid or by a metal-salen complex, the CO2 conversion is remarkably promoted by the bifunctional catalyst composed of the ionic liquid and the metal salen complex. It is assumed that the cooperation between the metal center (Lewis acid) of the metal-salen and the nucleophilic Cl- of the anion in the ionic liquid plays a key role in the cycloaddition reaction. However, the underlying synergistic details by the bifunctional catalyst are not clear. Herein, we focus on the mechanism and carry out kinetic analysis with the energy span model for the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by the bifunctional catalysts of metal (M)-salen complexes with ILs tethered to salen ligand (M = AlIII, CrIII, MnIII, CoIII and ZnII). Specifically, in Section 3.2 we identified the favorable mechanism using Al-salen complexes with which experiments have been conducted. Then we compared the catalytic performance of Al-salen complexes with the salen ligand substituted by four different ILs in Section 3.3 and examined the activity of the Al-salen complexes of salen ligand tethered with hydroxyl and amino functionalized ILs in Section 3.4. Sections 3.5 and 3.6 are devoted to the effects of the epoxide substituents and the central metal in salen complexes respectively. Section 3.7 addresses the catalytic performance of Co-salen complexes of salen ligand tethered by different ILs. The present comprehensive study will shed lights on the mechanism and provide guiding information for designing efficient CO2 conversion systems. 2 Models and computational details In the present paper, we will first examine the CO2 cycloaddition with PO along the three-step and two-step mechanisms by the bifunctional catalysts of Al-salen complexes with ILs illustrated in Scheme 1. Among the eight catalysts, Al-salen-Py and Al-salen-Im have been studied experimentally, and the others are elaborately constructed in the present paper. The difference between the catalysts Al-salen-Py, Al-salen-Im, Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP lies in the substituent group -R. The substituent group -R in Al-salen-Py, Al-salen-Im, Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP are pyridine, imidazole, quaternary ammonium and quaternary phosphonium ILs respectively. PyOH (PyNH2) and QNOH (QNNH2) are the hydroxyl (amino) functionalized pyridine and quaternary ammonium ILs. Scheme 2 illustrates the three-step and two-step mechanisms. The three-step mechanism proceeds PO ring opening, CO2 insertion and ring closure steps. There are two pathways, PathRO-IN-Al and PathRO-IN-H, belonging to the three-step mechanism because the ring can be opened by either Al metal center or H of the ionic liquid. In notation PathRO-IN-Al/PathRO-IN-H, RO means ring opening; IN refers to CO2 insertion; Al or H represents the Lewis acid center to activate the oxygen atom of PO or CO2. PathIN-RO-Al/PathIN-RO-H denotes that the pathway in which the ring opening and the CO2 insertion happen concertedly, and the oxygen atom of CO2 is activated by Lewis acid center Al/H. In the two-step mechanism, the ring opening and the CO2 insertion happen concertedly (i.e., they finish in the same step, Scheme 2). The second step is the ring closure. Similar to the three-step mechanism, the two-step mechanism also has two pathways PathIN-RO-Al and PathIN-RO-H. Totally four pathways were examined. All calculations were performed using B3LYP functional which has been employed by several groups [39,40] to calculate this cycloaddition reaction. In addition, the dispersive effect could not be ignored owing to the high molecular weight of the systems under study. So the B3LYP-D3BJ [41,42] functional was used along with 6-31G(d) [43] basis set implemented in Gaussian 16 program [44] for all the calculations. Introduction of diffuse basis on heavy atoms, 6-31+x002BG(d,p) [45,46], exerts negligible influence on all the geometries and does not change the favorable pathway and conclusion (Table S1). Optimizations were stopped when the default convergence criteria were met. The vibrational analysis at the same level was performed to characterize all the structures with a single imaginary frequency for a transition state and none for a reactant, product or intermediate. The intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [47] method was carried out to verify that the obtained transition states were connected to the desired local minima. To improve the estimation of calculated energies, single point energy calculations were conducted by using the def2-TZVP [48], and the solvent effect was taken into consideration with SMD [49] model in ethyl ether (Et2O) solvent [39]. The spin multiplicity of the Al-salen catalysis exists in low-lying singlet state, and the spin multiplicity of other metal-salen complexes were listed in Table S2. Molecular volumes were evaluated with the Multiwfn software [50]. The 3D structures were prepared using CYLView [51]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Active site Because there are two ionic liquid substituents in the salen ligand, there are four possible catalyst structures, three five-coordinated Al complexes and one six-coordinated complex (Table S3), depending on the position of the Cl- of the ionic liquid substituent. Cl- coordinating to the metal Al atom renders a six-coordinated aluminum species which is higher in energy than the five-coordinated aluminum species by 34.0 kJ/mol (Table S3). This result is in line with the experiment showing that the five-coordinated species is greatly favored in the equilibrium [15]. The most stable five-coordinated complex in which the two Cl- ions of ILs interact with the H atoms of the ILs and ligand (Table S3) was used for the following calculations. Wrapping-mode (Fac-Mer geometry in which the O-Al-O angle is 90°, and Fac-Fac geometry where the O-Al-O bond angle is 180°) of metal-salen catalysts is found to be important for explaining relevant experiments [52,53]. Nevertheless, all the calculations in the present paper were performed on the Fac-Mer geometry, not the Fac-Fac one, because the latter is much higher in energy than that of the former (Table S4). The molecular electrostatic potentials (MEP) (Fig. S1) of Al-salen-Py, Al-salen-Im, Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP show that the cation part of the ionic liquid substituent are baby blue which denotes positive potential. This means that the H atom of the cation part can play the same role as the metal center Al to activate the O atom of the PO or CO2, as long as the H atom sits at a position suitable for attacking the O atom, which brings about the PathRO-IN-H and PathIN-RO-H mentioned above. 3.2 Favorable pathway catalyzed by Al-salen-Py The barrier of uncatalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 and PO is at least 197.5 kJ/mol (Fig. S2), indicating that the reaction is difficult to take place in the absence of a catalyst. However, the common salen catalyst of which the substituent group is tertiary butyl catalyzes coupling reaction of CO2 and PO also with high free energy barrier 188.0 kJ/mol that is the lowest among the four pathways (Fig. S3). Thus, it is necessary to add extra catalyst or change its ligand of the metal salen catalyst system. As pointed out in Section 2, we will scrutinize two-step mechanism and three-step mechanism. Each mechanism consists of two pathways because the catalyst like Al-salen-Py has two Lewis acid centers, the metal Al and H of the IL substituent, which can activate the O atom of PO and CO2 (Scheme 2 and Fig. 1 ). Firstly we discuss PathRO-IN-Al, a three-step mechanism which includes (i) the PO ring opening accomplished through the metal Al activating the O atom and the nucleophile Cl- of the IL attacking the terminal carbon atom, (ii) the insertion of CO2, and (iii) the closure of the five-member ring to form the final product propylene carbonate. PathRO-IN-Al in which Cl- attacks the terminal carbon of PO was chosen because the energy span δE (smaller span indicates higher reaction rate [54–56].), 74.7 kJ/mol, is smaller than 84.3 kJ/mol for attacking the middle carbon (PathRO-IN-Al ', Fig. S4). This is likely due to less steric inhibition, as evidenced by the shorter C-Cl bond in the turnover frequency (TOF)-determining transition state (TDTS), TS1, in PathRO-IN-Al than that in PathRO-IN-Al ', 2.409 Å vs 2.527 Å (Fig. S5). As the previous work [21], we find the second step, CO2 insertion, is a barrierless process, which is supported by the scanned potential energy surface (Fig. S6). The final step, formation of the product propylene carbonate through the ring-closure of the Int3RO-IN-Al, needs to overcome a free energy barrier of 53.1 kJ/mol which is higher than that for the ring-opening step (47.6 kJ/mol). The other three-step mechanism, PathRO-IN-H, begins with activation of the O atom of PO by the H atom of the ionic liquid. The H atom activating the O atoms of PO or CO2 belongs to pyridine ring and has been marked with brown in Scheme 2. The difference between PathRO-IN-Al and PathRO-IN-H lies at the ring opening: it is opened by the H and Cl- in PathRO-IN-H, compared to that by the Al and Cl- in PathRO-IN-Al. The calculated energy span δE (108.7 kJ/mol) for PathRO-IN-H is 34 kJ/mol higher than that of PathRO-IN-Al. Thus, the favorable pathway of the three-step mechanism is PathRO-IN-Al. For the two-step mechanism, we also calculated two pathways. In PathIN-RO-Al the PO ring opening is realized via the simultaneous attacking the terminal C and the O atom of PO by the Cl- of ILs and the C atom of CO2 respectively. Note CO2 is coordinated to the Al center. The free energy barrier is calculated to be 84.2 kJ/mol. This step results in Int2IN-RO-Al (scheme 2, green), an opened five-membered ring. The final step, the five-membered ring closure, coincides the last step in PathRO-IN-Al. The calculated energy span δE is 141.4 kJ/mol, almost doubling the value of PathRO-IN-Al (74.7 kJ/mol). Hence, PathIN-RO-Al contributes negligibly to the product. The other pathway for the two-step mechanism is PathIN-RO-H. Its energy span is computed to be 168.9 kJ/mol which is higher than 141.4 kJ/mol for PathIN-RO-Al. Here, one can see that the three-step mechanism (PathRO-IN-Al and PathRO-IN-H) is kinetically more favorable than the two-step mechanism (PathIN-RO-Al and PathIN-RO-H). This phenomenon can be rationalized with the calculated NPA (natural population analysis) charges on the Al atom, the H atom and the Cl-. The charges on the Al/H atom in PathRO-IN-Al/PathRO-IN-H are 1.898/0.308 |e| which are higher than 1.880/0.295 |e| in PathIN-RO-Al/PathIN-RO-H, and the charges on the nucleophile Cl- are −0.657/−0.509 |e| in PathRO-IN-Al /PathRO-IN-H, and −0.704/−0.605 |e| in PathIN-RO-Al/PathIN-RO-H; the more positive/negative charges in Lewis acid center/nucleophile, the easier the synergistic ring opening. The above analysis reveals that the three-step mechanisms are favored over the two-step ones. The activity of the Al atom as Lewis acid is higher than that of the H atom in the ILs and the most favorable pathway is PathRO-IN-Al of the three-step mechanism. 3.3 Effect of nonfunctionalized IL substituents The above results indicate that PathRO-IN-Al is the most favorable. To understand the effect of traditional nonfunctionalized IL substituents on the CO2 conversion, we computed the free energy profiles of CO2 conversion along PathRO-IN-Al catalyzed by Al-salen-Py, Al-salen-Im, Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP (Fig. 2 ). The ball-and-stick structures of the transition states and intermediates are displayed in Fig. S7. As can be seen from Fig. 2, the TDTS is the TS1 for Al-salen-Im with the δE of 83.5 kJ/mol which is higher than 74.7 kJ/mol for Al-salen-Py. This result is in good agreement with the experiment [15] showing that the activity of Al-salen-Py is higher than that of Al-salen-Im. The δEs for Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP are 60.3 kJ/mol and 59.3 kJ/mol, respectively, implying that the catalytic activity of Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP is even higher than that of Al-salen-Py. The activity trend can be roughly understood with the nucleophilicity characterized by the NPA charges on the nucleophile Cl- in TS1IL: −0.639 |e| (Al-salen-Im) < −0.657 |e| (Al-salen-Py) < −0.671 |e| (Al-salen-QP) < −0.685 |e| (Al-salen-QN). Our calculated NPA charges on Cl- do show that systems whose Cl- are more negatively charged tend to be more active. 3.4 Effect of hydroxyl and amino functionalized ILs substituents It has been reported that functionalized ILs possess higher activity than nonfunctionalized ILs [57,58]. Inspired by this, we studied CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by Al-salen complexes of salen ligands appended with hydroxyl and amino functionalized ionic liquids: Al-salen-PyOH, Al-salen-QNOH, Al-salen-PyNH2 and Al-salen-QNNH2 (Scheme 1). Fig. 3 and 4 display the potential energy profiles and relevant optimized structures of species involved in the coupling reaction are collected in Fig. S8. The calculated δEs are 81.8, 65.2, 63.7 and 57.6 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyOH, Al-salen-QNOH, Al-salen-PyNH2 and Al-salen-QNNH2 respectively. The energy span ordering also coincides with the charges on Cl-: −0.505 |e| (Al-salen-PyOH) < −0.576 |e| (Al-salen-PyNH2) < −0.629 |e| (Al-salen-QNOH) < −0.660 |e| (Al-salen-QNNH2). In fact, the δEs correlate linearly with the NPA charges on the nucleophile Cl- in TS1 with R2 = 0.85. The energy span 81.8 and 65.2 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyOH and Al-salen-QNOH are larger than 74.7 and 60.3 kJ/mol for the corresponding nonfunctionalized ILs Al-salen-Py and Al-salen-QN. Therefore, hydroxyl functionalized ILs show no enhanced activity of CO2 conversion. On the contrary, the calculated δEs, 63.7 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyNH2 and 57.6 kJ/mol for Al-salen-QNNH2 are smaller than the corresponding values for Al-salen-Py/Al-salen-QN (74.7/60.3 kJ/mol). This result indicates that amino functionalized ILs tethered to the Al-salen can promote the catalytic performance for CO2 conversion. We would like to mention that although hydroxyl functionalized ILs do not facilitate the activity of CO2 conversion, the H atom in the OH group possesses higher activity to activate the O atom of PO than the H atom of nonfunctionalized ILs, as evidenced by our calculated energy span for PathRO-INH: 85.0 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyOH (See Fig. S9), compared to 108.7 kJ/mol for Al-salen-Py. In fact, according to the computed energy span, 81.8 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyOH (PathRO-IN-Al), 85.0 kJ/mol for Al-salen-PyOH (PathRO-IN-H) and 108.7 kJ/mol for Al-salen-Py (PathRO-IN-H), one can get the following activation sequence to the O atom of PO: the metal Al center > the H atom in the OH group > the H atom in nonfunctionalized IL substituent. Results for Al-salen-QNOH and Al-salen-QN lead to the same conclusion. 3.5 Effects of the substrate epoxides Experiments demonstrate that ethylene oxide (EO, 2) exhibits similar reactivity for the CO2 conversion as PO (1) (Table 1) [15]. On the contrary, cyclohexene oxide (CO, 3) is less active than PO. To explore the effect of the epoxide substituent on the cycloaddition, we brought compounds 4–6 (Table 1 ) into investigation. These compounds are computationally economic and helpful for figuring out the effect of substrates, although some of them are rarely used experimentally. Fig. S10 depicts the potential energy surfaces and Fig. S11 shows the relevant optimized structures. It is seen from Table 1 and Fig. S10 that δE of 81.0 kJ/mol (EO, 2) is slightly higher than 74.7 kJ/mol (PO, 1) whereas the energy span of CO (3), 86.0 kJ/mol, is 11.3 kJ/mol higher than that of PO. All these results agree with the available experimental observation [15], supporting our proposed mechanism as well as our computational methodology. The substrate effect can be roughly discussed from the steric effect and electronic effect. Here the former is characterized by the volume and the latter by NPA charges on the terminal carbon atom (QC) and the oxygen atom (QO) of the epoxides (for those with TS1 being the TDTS). The TDI and TDTS for 1, 2 and 6 are the corresponding reactants and TS1s. Substrate 6 has the lowest span, though it has the largest substituent. In fact, if the steric effect dominates the energy span, one would get δE (6) < δE (1) < δE (2), which is right opposite to our results (Table 1). Hence, the energy span is not controlled by the steric effect. Since TS1 is the key state determining the energy span, factors stabilizing TS1 would low the energy span. From scheme 2 one can see that the substrate interacts with the catalyst via the binding of the Lewis acid center Al to the epoxide O atom and the nucleophile Cl- to the terminal C atom. Therefore, more/less negative charges on the O/C atom would stabilize the TS1s and result in lower energy span. This is just what one observes in Table 1: substrate 6 which has the lowest energy span possesses the lowest negative charges on the C, −0.128 |e|. In fact, there is a linear relationship (R2 = 0.92) between the energy span and QC for 1, 2 and 6. Further analysis reveals that QO does not correlate with the energy span, indicating that the interaction between the Cl- and the attacked C atom is important in stabilizing TS1. These results imply that epoxides with substituents that lower the negative charges on the attacked carbon atom favor the CO2 conversion. For substrates 3 and 5, the TDTSs are TS3 and the charges QO and QC cannot be used to characterize the electronic effect of the substituent because CO2 has bonded to the substrate (Scheme 2). Substrate 3 has the higher energy span mainly due to a larger substituent which bonds to the attacked carbon atom. 3.6 Effects of the metal center in the salen complexes So far we have only studied Al-salen complexes as catalysts for CO2 conversion. In reality, M-salen complexes [M =AlIII, CrIII, MnIII, CoIII and ZnII] are often used or investigated in catalysis [17,59–61]. To explore the effect of the central metal ions on the conversion, we calculated the kinetics and thermodynamics of CO2 conversion catalyzed by M-salen-Py along PathRO-IN-Al (Fig. 5 ). Relevant optimized structures of species involved in the coupling reaction are collected in Fig. S12. As shown in Fig. 5, although different complexes have different TDTS or TDI, the energy span model analysis reveals that the δE (49.8 kJ/mol) of Co-salen-Py catalyst is the smallest among the five catalysts, followed by 56.6 kJ/mol (Cr-salen-Py). The energy span of Zn-salen-Py is similar to the Al-salen-Py, with the δE being 74.6 kJ/mol. Among these metal-salen complexes, Mn-salen-Py (103.6 kJ/mol) shows least activity. The calculated energy span predicts the following activity sequence: CoIII > CrIII > ZnII ~ AlIII > MnIII. Remember the energy span is related to the activation of the oxygen atom of PO, as demonstrated by the activity ordering of Al > the H in the OH group > the H in IL. Thus, the low activity or large energy span of Mn-salen-Py can be traced back to the activation of Mn to the oxygen atom of PO. Indeed, the above sequence is found to be consistent with the bond length between metal center and the O of PO (M-O) in the reaction complexes Int1M (Co-O: 1.982 Å; Cr-O: 2.102 Å; Zn-O: 2.149 Å; Al-O: 2.175 Å; Mn-O: 2.450 Å). Among the three transition metals Co, Cr, and Mn, the Mn-O bond is the longest, and the Co-O length is the shortest. This can be rationalized with the crystal field stabilization energy (CFSE) in octahedral field. The ground state spin multiplicity of Co-salen-Py, Cr-salen-Py and Mn-salen-Py is 1, 4 and 5, respectively. The number of electron in low-lying/high-lying t2g/eg orbitals are 6/0, 3/0 and 3/1 for CoIII, CrIII and MnIII. Hence, CoIII with 3d6 electron configuration has the largest CFSE, and MnIII with 3d4 configuration has the smallest CFSE. Further analysis shows that the energy span correlates linearly with the M-O bond length with R2 = 0.95 (Fig. 6 ). This result implies that one may estimate the energy span or catalytic performance of different metal-salen complexes by studying the distance between the metal and the O atom of epoxide in the reaction complexes. This finding is quite informative because it provides us a descriptor to screen better catalysts for CO2 conversion without invoking the computationally expensive transition state location. The maximum difference in energy span reaches 53.8 kJ/mol for the five metal salen complexes (Table 2 ), compared to 26.1 kJ/mol for different substrates (Table 1). Thus, to pursue high CO2 conversion efficiency, utilization of suitable metal-salen complexes is more effective than using active substrates. 3.7 Comparison of Co-salen complexes and Al-salen complexes Considering Co-salen-Py shows the best activity among the five M-salen-Py, we here investigate the effect of IL on the catalytic performance of Co-salen complexes, aiming to find the best metal-salen catalyst. All the calculations are along PathRO-IN-Al (Table 3 and Fig. S13). Relevant optimized structures of species involved in the coupling reaction are collected in Fig. S14. For the four nonfunctionalized IL tethered metal-salen complexes, Co-salen-Py and Co-salen-Im are much more active than the Al counterparts. However, Co-salen-QN and Co-alen-QP are inferior to the corresponding Al complexes, though the difference in energy span is less than 4 kJ/mol. This result implies that ILs can also exert notable influence on the catalytic activity of the catalysts, even though the metal center plays a dominant role. In fact, the maximum difference in energy span among the eight Co-salen catalysts are ~30 kJ/mol, indicating that one can adjust the catalytic activity by choosing suitable ILs. All the Co-salen complexes of the four functionalized ILs are more active than the corresponding Al-salen complexes, manifesting the role of the metal center. The energy span of the eight Co-salen-complexes is 9.5 kJ/mol smaller than that of the Al-salen-complexes on average. Co-salen-PyNH2 is the most active and Al-salen-QNNH2 shows the highest activity. Thus metal-salen complexes tethered with amino functionalized ILs exhibit promising activity to CO2 conversion to propylene carbonate. Quantitatively, on the basis of calculated energy span, the averaged activity of Co-salen complexes at room temperature is about 50 times that of Al-salen counterparts which are often used for CO2 conversion. Thus it is worthy to test Co-salen complexes experimentally. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have performed a comprehensive and theoretical study on the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides catalyzed by the single-component bifunctional catalysts of metal salen complexes tethered with various ionic liquids. We indentified the favorable mechanism and reaction pathway, and investigated the influence of ionic liquids, substituents in epoxides, and central metal ion in salen complexes. On the basis of detailed analyses, the following conclusions can be drawn. Among all the possible pathways studied, the most favorable one is PathRO-IN-Al which comprises ring-opening triggered by the metal center Al, barrierless CO2 insertion and ring-closure. Among the four metal-salen complexes tethered by nonfunctionalized ionic liquids, Al-salen-QN and Al-salen-QP exhibit the higher catalytic efficiency for the CO2 conversion. While hydroxyl functionalized ionic liquids do not show the propensity to promote the catalytic performance as anticipated, amino functionalized ionic liquids can enhance the catalytic activity notably. For epoxides with the substituents not bonded to the attacked carbon atoms, electronic effect of the substituent is more significant than the steric effect. The sequence of the catalytic activity of the metal salen complexes tethered by pyridine ionic liquid is: CoIII > CrIII > ZnII ~ AlIII > MnIII. Catalytic activity correlates linearly with the bond distance between the metal ion and the oxygen atom of epoxide. Co-salen complexes are generally more active than the Al-salen counterparts and are worthy being tested experimentally. The central metal ions play more important role than ionic liquids and epoxides for CO2 conversion. Although appropriate metal-salen complexes are important, an efficient CO2 conversion system should feature a perfect combination of metal-salen, ionic liquid and epoxide. coredata.dc:description: A series of bifunctional metal-salen complexes bearing ionic liquid substituents were investigated as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide (CO2) and epoxides using density functional theory (DFT) and energy span model. Detailed studies reveal that the three-step mechanism involving the ring-opening of propylene oxide (PO), CO2 insertion, and ring-closure to the cyclic carbonate is kinetically more favorable than the two-step mechanism. The effect of ionic liquids, epoxide substituents and metal center of the metal-salen complexes were explored. Amino functionalized ionic liquids substituents tethered to the salen ligand of the metal-salen complexes performed well. Epoxide substituents affect the cycloaddition mainly through the electronic effect and the substituent that lowers the negative charges of the ring carbon atom to be attacked favors the cycloaddition. When the salen ligand is fixed, the catalytic activity metal-salen complexes can be measured by the interaction between the oxygen atom (O) of epoxides and the central metal (M) and there is a linear relationship between the energy span and the M-O bond length, which can be used as a descriptor to screen CO2 conversion catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical investigation on conversion of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates by bifunctional metal-salen complexes bearing ionic liquid substsituents
